content:
# MATH 121 - Linear Algebra

I notice that you're asking about MATH 121, but according to your academic record, you've already taken this course. Nevertheless, here's the information about the course:

## Course Details
- **Instructor:** John Cain
- **Term:** 2026 Spring
- **Overall Rating:** 4.3/5.0 (which is quite good)
- **Mean Hours per Week:** Not available in the data provided

## Course Description
This is a second course in linear algebra, with an emphasis on understanding linear algebra at a more abstract level and learning to read and write proofs. Topics include real and complex vector spaces, linear transformations, and eigenvalues and eigenvectors.

## Requirements
Anti-requisite: Not to be taken in addition to Mathematics 22a, 23a, 25a, or 55a.

## Student Feedback
- "Very open/exploratory course. You can tell that Dylan REALLY cares about his students. I walked away from the class learning more about my relationship with math and learning. The class could have been better with more structure but it was what I needed for the semester. It is a very easy going course."
- "Take Math 121 :)"
- "If you take this course, be sure to hold yourself accountable. Because of its looser structure, it is easy to allow yourself to fall a bit behind."

## Note
Since you've already taken MATH 121 according to your academic record, you might want to consider more advanced mathematics courses if you're looking for additional math credits. As a Mathematics concentrator, you might want to explore other upper-level courses that build on the linear algebra foundation you've established.

Is there a specific reason you're asking about a course you've already taken, or would you like information about other mathematics courses?

courseData.description: This is a second course in linear algebra, with an emphasis on understanding linear algebra at a more abstract level and learning to read and write proofs. Topics include real and complex vector spaces, linear transformations, and eigenvalues and eigenvectors.
courseData.subject: Mathematics
courseData.course_requirements: Anti-req: Not to be taken in addition to Mathematics 22a, 23a or 25a or 55a.
courseData.recommended_prep: Mathematics 19b or 21b or an equivalent background in mathematics.
courseData.comments: ["Very open/exploratory course. you can tell that Dylan REALLY cares about his students. I walked away from the class learning more about my relationship with math and learning. The class could have been better with more structure but it was what I needed for the semester. It is a very easy going course","Take Math 121 :)","If you take this course, be sure to hold yourself accountable. Because of its looser structure, it is easy to allow yourself to fall a bit behind.","This class is what you make of it – you can do as much or as little as you like to get by. If you do wish to do more, it's certainly possible and can be a great mathematics course in this regard, especially with experience writing proofs.","This is a great intro to proofs! The topics are interesting, but I strongly recommend taking Math 21b beforehand.","This is a very difficult class that is very chill if you want it to be. ONLY take this class if you really want to learn math AND are VERY self–guided.","With Dylan Wilson, there is opportunity to explore if you have the time and motivation. There are no grades, which means that you have to be *really* self–driven to make the class what you want. I did not, and so I feel like I did not get much out of the class. I will be self–studying MIT's 18.06 Linear Algebra class to make up for my lack of foundational linear alg knowledge.\n\nWhen I tried to pset with peers, many politely declined because they valued the class as lower relative to their other classes. Thus, the lack of grading in this class RELATIVE to other classes means that there was a lack of community through struggle (lol). I wish I got to know my peers better!! They seemed like cool people.","This class is much more proof–based than something like Math 21b, and I would recommend having 21b under your belt beforehand, because without it, material in proof format can seem much more confusing. Dylan was great and super helpful, though not sure what this class under another professor would be like.","If you have any interest in upper level mathematics, you should take this class. It will give you all the necessary tools you need to pursue anything else you would choose to in the department.","If Dylan Wilson is teaching this class – take it. Best professor I've had in terms of actually prioritizing learning over completionism. The course material is still a little dry – it's proof–based linear algebra, but Dylan makes up for it.","Dylan is an AMAZING professor. I have never felt safe in a math classroom to inquire and genuinely learn until I took Dylan's class/had him as a professor. He really emphasizes learning to learn instead of for an output (grade). He is also great at explaining difficult concepts, and some things I didn't understand in 21b suddenly clicked in 121. Be wary of who is teaching this though––experience is highly dependent on the instructor.","This class has a ton of flexibility. If you can manage things on your own without outside structure, then take this class! Dylan is super nice and puts an emphasis on learning purely for learning's sake. If you're not great with a lot of flexibility and need external structure, don't take this. It's very self guided, so you won't be able to learn just with what's given.","Take this class; it will definitely expand your understanding in general beyond math.","It is probably not worth your time.","Great class"]

content: mean hours per week of math 121?

# MATH 121 - Mean Hours per Week

According to the workload data available:

**MATH 121 (Linear Algebra)** has a mean workload of **8.0 hours per week**.

This is considered a moderate workload for a mathematics course. The course also has a very strong Q Score of 4.74, indicating students rate it highly despite the moderate time commitment.

As a Mathematics concentrator who has already taken this course, you might find it useful to know that this 8-hour weekly commitment is typical for upper-level mathematics courses that emphasize proof-writing and abstract concepts.

content: what course reqs do i have left for math concentration

# Mathematics Concentration Requirements Analysis

Based on your academic record as a Mathematics concentrator, I'll analyze what requirements you still need to fulfill.

## Courses You've Already Taken

You have completed the following mathematics courses:
- MATH 21A (Introduction to Calculus)
- MATH 121 (Linear Algebra)
- MATH 136 (Differential Geometry)

## Core Requirements Analysis

For the Mathematics concentration, you need to fulfill the following categories:

### Basic Requirements
1. ✅ **Calculus fundamentals**: Satisfied with MATH 21A
2. ❌ **Multivariable Calculus**: You need to take MATH 21B or equivalent
3. ✅ **Linear Algebra**: Satisfied with MATH 121
4. ❌ **Abstract Algebra**: You need to take MATH 122 or equivalent

### Advanced Requirements
You need a total of 8-12 mathematics courses (depending on placement), including:
- At least 4 courses at the 100-level or higher
- Currently, you have completed 2 courses at the 100-level (MATH 121 and MATH 136)
- You need at least 2 more 100-level mathematics courses

### Tutorial Requirement
❌ You need to fulfill the math tutorial requirement (usually MATH 99R)

## Recommended Next Steps

1. Complete your **Multivariable Calculus** requirement with MATH 21B
2. Take **Abstract Algebra** (MATH 122)
3. Enroll in at least 2 more 100-level mathematics courses
4. Complete the **tutorial requirement** (MATH 99R)

## Note on Course Selection

Based on your academic history, which includes several Computer Science and Philosophy courses, you might consider:
- MATH 152 (Discrete Mathematics) which connects well with your CS background
- MATH 141 (Introduction to Mathematical Logic) which complements your philosophy coursework
- MATH 123 (Algebra II) as a follow-up to the abstract algebra requirement

Would you like more detailed information about any specific requirement or recommended courses?
wait so just list out in bullets what math classes i have to take (range, type, or exact class)

# Remaining Mathematics Concentration Requirements

Based on your academic record as a Mathematics concentrator, here's a straightforward list of what you still need to complete:

## Core Requirements
* **Multivariable Calculus**: MATH 21B (or equivalent)
* **Abstract Algebra**: MATH 122 (or equivalent)
* **Tutorial Requirement**: MATH 99R

## Advanced Requirements
* **Additional 100-level courses**: At least 2 more mathematics courses at the 100-level
  * You currently have MATH 121 and MATH 136
  * Need 2 more to reach the minimum of 4 required 100-level courses

## Total Course Count
* You need to complete a total of 8-12 mathematics courses for the concentration
* You currently have completed 3 mathematics courses (MATH 21A, MATH 121, MATH 136)
* You need at least 5 more mathematics courses to complete the concentration

That's the complete list of what you still need to fulfill your Mathematics concentration requirements.
